Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Magneto-Electric Nanostructures for Novel Microwave Signal Processing Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research is to fabricate and study the magneto-electric interactions in novel one-dimensional ferromagnetic-ferroelectric nanostructures, and to exploit them for innovative device applications. The program is motivated by theoretical models that suggest much stronger interactions in such nanostructure geometries than in standard thin films and laminate structures. The approach is to synthesize nanowire and nanotube composites consisting of ferroelectric materials, such as lead zirconium titanante or barium titanate, with ferrimagnetic nickel- or cobalt ferrite.

Intellectual Merit:
A comprehensive research program is planned consisting of the following components: sample fabrication, structural characterization, magneto-electric interaction studies spanning a wide frequency range, device studies, and theoretical modeling. Efforts will focus on the creation of novel nanostructures using innovative processing methods and examine their use for a new class of microwave devices that are both electric and magnetic field tunable. At the University of Alabama, the PI will lead the sample fabrication, structural characterization and device fabrication efforts; while the physical property measurements, theoretical studies and device applications will be led by the PI at Oakland University.

Broader Impact:
The efforts will bring together a multidisciplinary team of investigators that will make significant contributions to scientific knowledge, education outreach and infrastructure, and potentially lead to a host of next-generation devices for the national defense and consumer electronics. The program will provide support for graduate and undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities, and contribute to their broad interdisciplinary training. Project personnel will collaborate with local schools to facilitate participation by high school students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Single phase multiferroics exhibit simultaneous ferroelectric and magnetic ordering in the same material system. As a result, they have a spontaneous magnetization that can be switched by an applied magnetic field, a spontaneous polarization that can be switched by an applied electric field, and often there is some coupling between the two. Multiferroic materials are potentially advantageous for device miniaturization and can lead to additional functionalities, so that a single device component can perform more than one task. However, attempts to design multiferroics that combine ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity in the same phase have proved unexpectedly difficult, because the usual atomic-level mechanisms driving ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity are mutually exclusive. Although a few single phase multiferroic materials have been discovered by exploiting alternative mechanisms that lead to ferroelectricity or magnetism, none of them have proven suitable thus far for practical applications because of the very weak electric and magnetic polarization and cross coupling at room temperature.

On the other hand, strong room-temperature magnetoelectric coupling has been achieved via the stress mediation in two-phase composite multiferroics that consist of a ferroelectric and a ferromagnetic (ferrimagnetic) constituent.  The strain induced by an electric field in the ferroelectric phase can be transmitted on to the ferromagnetic phase in the form of magnetostriction, resulting in a change in magnetization. Such magnetoelectric effect can be enhanced if the coupling at the interface is large. Therefore, composite multiferroics with large surface area and strongly ferroelastic/ magnetostrictive constituents are particularly attractive.

The goals of the project were to fabricate and study the ME interactions in novel one-dimensional (1-D) ferroelectric-ferrimagnetic nanostructures, and to exploit them for device applications. The primary focus was on the synthesis and characterization of ferroelectric-ferrimagnetic layered structures, analysis of magneto-electric interactions, and to achieve theoretically predicted giant ME voltage coefficients. At the University of Alabama (UA), the work focused on sample fabrication, structural characterization and device fabrication efforts; while the ME property measurements, theoretical studies and device applications were led by the PI at Oakland University (OU), Prof. Gopalan Srinivasan. Major accomplishments of efforts at UA include:

 -  Theory of magnetoelectric effect in nanobilayers and 1-D nanocomposites.

 - Fabrication and properties of 1-D barium titanate (ferroelectric) - cobalt ferrite (ferrimagnetic) structures on magnesium oxide nanowire template.

 -  Solution-phase synthesis of barium titanate nanostructures and their properties.

 - Self assembly and magnetic properties of shape-controlled monodisperse ferrite and chalcospinel nanocrystals.

 -  1-D cobalt ferrite coated barium titanate nanostructure composites and their properties.

       The results have resulted in 11 journal publications, four of them in collaboration with Prof. Srinivasan. Five invited talks and several contributed presentations based on the project have also been presented. Four REU students worked on the project during the period 2008 - 2010.
